docTitle.titlePart:
Codon optimization for high-level expression of HIV-1 subtype-C envelope
glycoprotein in vitro.

byline.docAuthor: Huang Y, Chen Z, Ip JE, Zhao X, Ho DD;

front.reference:
Conference on Retroviruses and
Opportunistic Infections.
7th Conf Retrovir Oppor Infect Jan 30 Feb 2 2000 Conf Retrovir Oppor Infect 7th
2000 San Franc Calif. 2000 Jan 30-Feb 2; 7: 225 (abstract 803).
front.note: Aaron Diamond AIDS Res. Ctr., The Rockefeller Univ., New York.
front.div:
Codon bias has been observed in many species. The preferential use of codons for a
given gene is positively correlated with its expression efficiency. In an attempt to
study the effects of codon usage in the context of DNA vaccination against HIV-1, we
have generated a synthetic HIV-1 subtype-C (CHN19) envelope gene in which the
codons of every single amino acid were optimized for high expression in human cells.
We then cloned our optimized gene into the pcDNA1.1 expression vector. In transient
expression assays, we showed that codon optimization significantly increases the
level of HIV-1 envelope expression (approximately 100 fold) as compared to that of
the wild-type sequence in vitro. Moreover, the enhanced expression of envelope
proteins also leads to an increase in the titer of retroviral pseudotypes (approximately
10 fold). Furthermore, a chimeric SHIV-C bearing this codon-optimized HIV-1 gp120
is replication-competent with faster growth kinetics. These in vitro observations
suggest that optimization of HIV-1 envelope not only enhanced the envelope
expression, but also improved the functional characteristics of HIV-1 envelope
glycoprotein in vitro. The in vivo impact of this codon-optimized DNA vaccine will
be examined in rhesus macaques.
